thread.title: High schools: Meissner’s four goals powers Clippers
thread.title_full: High schools: Meissner’s four goals powers Clippers

author: Cape Cod Times sports@capecodonline.com
title: High schools: Meissner’s four goals powers Clippers
text: Posted Oct. 25, 2015 at 9:39 PM By Cape Cod Times Posted Oct. 25, 2015 at 9:39 PM » Social News EAST FALMOUTH -- Erika Meissner knocked in four goals, powering the Falmouth Clippers to a 5-0 field hockey win against the Nantucket Whalers on Sunday. Falmouth (7-5-3) needs one more win in its last four games to qualify for the playoffs. The Clippers led 2-0 at halftime, both on goals by Meissner. She scored twice more in the second half, with Hannah Corner providing the fifth goal. Alexia Meissner assisted on two of sister Erika Meissner’s goals. Emma Callahan also recorded two assists and was part of an outstanding Falmouth midfield that also included cousin Hannah Callahan and Jordan Willis. Molly Duff-Still made three saves in goal against Nantucket (6-8-1) for her fifth shutout of the year. FOOTBALL St. John Paul II 42, Matignon/St. Joseph Prep 28: Cole Campbell scored twice in a dominant first quarter, and the St. John Paul II Lions clinched both a share of the Catholic Conference Small title and a spot in the Division 6 South playoffs with their win over Matignon/St. Joseph on Saturday night at Mass. Maritime Academy’s Clean Harbors Stadium in Buzzards Bay. Campbell returned the opening kickoff 82 yards for a touchdown, with Richard Mulcahy running in the two-pointer for an 8-0 lead. Johnny Warden connected with Campbell on a 40-yard touchdown pass later in the first quarter, then hit sophomore Troy Chicco on a 5-yard pass for a 30-0 lead in the second quarter. It was Chicco's first varsity touchdown. Warden also rushed for a touchdown in the first. Matignon (0-6, 0-5 Catholic Small) pulled to within 30-12 in the fourth, but freshman Kevin Duarte answered with a 47-yard touchdown run for the Lions (4-3, 4-1 Catholic Small), his first at the varsity level. Duarte later added a 58-yard score for a 42-20 lead. VOLLEYBALL Barnstable wins in Medfield: The Barnstable girls volleyball team won the Medfield Open Volleyball Tournament on Saturday, finishing undefeated on the day. The Medfield Open features several of the top teams in the state, with the Red Raiders beating Hopkinton, 25-18, 27-25, Bishop Feehan, 25-16, 25-17 and Mansfield 25-23, 25-13 in morning pool play. They bested Minnechaug 25-13, 25-11, Medfield 25-17, 25-15 and Duxbury 25-18, 25-23 in the evening pool. Barnstable then beat Andover 25-19, 25-22 in the finals to win the tournament. ROWING Nauset rowers medal: Rowers representing Nauset High and Cape Cod Rowing followed up last week's Head of the Charles Regatta by winning the Overall Team Points Trophy for Sculling at the first Massachusetts Championship Regatta on Saturday in Worcester. In the junior women's double, Audrey Calianos and Emily Conway teamed up to win gold, with teammates Laurel Fournier and Grace Cox taking silver. All four girls also won silver in the junior women's varsity four race. Kelly Glennon won gold in the junior women's single race. In the junior men's double, Michael Cabral and Jabob Awalt earned silver medals. Oliver Launoy won silver in the junior men's single. In last week’s Head of the Charles, Glennon placed 18th as the only youth single sculler from Cape Cod competing against rowers from around the world. CROSS COUNTRY Three locals set records: Sturgis East’s Brian Kelsey and Caroline Sullivan and Nauset’s Brian Brooks all set records in their wins at the 5th Annual Bob McIntyre Twilight Cross Country Meet on Saturday at the Barnstable Fairgrounds in East Falmouth. Kelsey won the Division 2 junior varsity boys race in 17 minutes,28.3 seconds, just 0.24 seconds ahead of teammate Cameron Henchy. Sandwich’s Kyle Gendreau was the only other local top-20 runner, taking 16th in 18:52.51. Sullivan won the Division 2 JV girls race in 20:43.52. Teammate Katie Reinhardt was fifth in 21:19, and Blue Knight runner Jenna Sweeney placed seventh in 21:29.21. Brooks won the sophomore boys race in 15:55.2, breaking a course record set in 2012 by 20 seconds. Sandwich’s Emily Duryea was the top local finisher among the sophomore girls, placing 15th in 20:07.33. D-Y’s Carly Coughlin placed seventh in the freshman girls race in 12:36.90. Barnstable finished 15th in the boys Division 1 varsity race, which Northampton’s Liam Sullivan won in 15:16.28 but Saint John’s won as a team. The Red Raider girls finished 22nd, with Lincoln-Sudbury winning and Ariel Keklak first overall in 17:25.16. Sturgis West as a team finished 14th in the Division 2 varsity race, followed by Monomoy in 26th and Falmouth in 29th. The Clippers placed 12th in the Division 2 girls race; Sturgis West finished 16th. Parker Chart’s Zach Rolfe won the Div. 2 boys race in 15:47.41, but Hopedale finished first as a team. Bellingham’s Sarah Edwards won the girls in 17:51.44, but Milton finished first as a team. Wellesley finished third in Division 1 boys and fourth in Division 1 girls to claim the 2nd Annual Bob Glennon Trophy for the school with the best combined score. By Cape Cod Times
